Stern winter no longer prevails,</br>His brow of severity bends,</br>The snow is dissolv'd in the vales,</br>The north all his fury suspends:</br>The stream, late so turbid and full,</br>Innundation pour'd over its mound;</br>Now limpid and slow to the pool,</br>Its waters glide peaceably down.

The blest revolution appears,</br>It comes on the wings of the breeze;</br>Yon cloud that dissolves into tears,</br>Expands the green robe of the trees.</br>The daisy bestuds the fresh plain,</br>The cowslip diffuses perfume,</br>The Graces, a beautiful train,</br>Revive in the season of bloom.

From the fir, in the midst of the grove,</br>The stock-dove, in passionate lay,</br>Pours melting effusions of love,</br>As opens or closes the day.</br>The blackbird is up with the morn,</br>To serenade enters the bush;</br>Whilst music more shrill, from the thorn,</br>Proclaims the delight of the thrush.

Does the east brighten wide with the dawn?</br>The lark from her pillow of green</br>Ascends from dew-spangled lawn,</br>Ambitiously rising is seen.</br>In vain do we follow her flight,</br>She mocks the pursuit of our eyes,</br>And sings from so distant a height,</br>She seems invelop'd in the skies.

How mutual's the toil of the day,</br>The rook and his loud-cawing mate,</br>The architect's labour display,</br>In skill most amazingly great;</br>Enfork'd in the elms lofty spray,</br>The branches intwisting among,</br>In cradle compacted of clay,</br>Securely they pillow their young.

The chaffinch, mechanic, whose art,</br>Ye warblers, you can excel,</br>Where the sprays in a thicket dispart,</br>Has finished her gray-mossy cell.</br>Without how enamell'd it seems,</br>How elegant, artful, and round,</br>Instudded as brilliant it beams,</br>A brilliant where sparkles abound.

The wren, of rotundity fond,</br>Her Ranelagh pins to the wall,</br>To the pollard that bends on the pond,</br>Or the thatch that projects from the stall.</br>Ye feather'd musicians of spring,</br>Your nests may no danger annoy;</br>O may the fatigue of your wing,</br>Your broodlings mature into joy.

What blessings the rustics await,</br>The season they hail with a smile!</br>How happy's the husbandman's fate!</br>Content is the offspring of toil.</br>At night, from the labour of day,</br>The faithful delight of his heart,</br>Meets her lord on his long-custom'd way,</br>The raptures of truth to impart.

Ye much-envied scenes of repose,</br>Dear sylvan-sequester'd retreats,</br>Where innocence shields from the woes</br>Attendant on luxury's seats.</br>Here Nature's thy throne, and behold,</br>In the cot, on the verge of the dell,</br>Tho' the roof is not fretted with gold,</br>Thy virtues, Simplicity, dwell.

The morning's first visit attend,</br>Shall we watch for Aurora's first beam,</br>Then, Celadon, shall we, my friend,</br>Purloin from the stores of the stream.</br>Afar from the clack of the mill,</br>We'll stray to the head of the brook,</br>Or shall we curve round with the rill,</br>And practise the wiles of the hook.

The trout in his moss-fashion'd bed,</br>Observe all his gay-speckled pride,</br>How bright are his patches of red,</br>Live rubies that bleed in the tide!</br>Shall he bask in his sun-courted ray,</br>Still tenant his oozy recess,</br>Clash the current disporting in play,</br>Or shall we his pastime distress?

Ah, no, your more delicate breast</br>Forbids an enjoyment to gain,</br>Forbids any pleasure to rest,</br>Which flows from inflicting a pain.</br>Let others illusion design,</br>We'll scorn th' unwary to cheat,</br>Surrender the rod and the line,</br>And spurn from amusement deceit.

Your muse shall the season declare,</br>Your muse, not the least of the nine,</br>And pardon, should I for a share</br>Attempt your soft essays to join.</br>To Pan let us offer the song,</br>Perchance he may favour the lay,</br>Which serves the sweet theme to prolong,</br>For April's the mother of May.</br>
